baseline_groups.claim_summary: Belief adjustments track Bayesian benchmark for good news in No-Resolution treatment
baseline_groups.notes: Coef=0.665, p<0.001. Subjects respond strongly to good news.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Belief adjustments weakly track Bayesian benchmark for bad news in No-Resolution (motivated reasoning)
baseline_groups.notes: Coef=0.076, p=0.672. Subjects largely ignore bad news -- evidence of motivated beliefs.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Resolution treatment restores responsiveness to good news
Resolution treatment restores responsiveness to bad news
baseline_groups.notes: Coef=0.645, p=0.010. Key finding: anticipation of resolution eliminates the good/bad news asymmetry.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Signal affects perceived study performance importance (No-Resolution)
Signal affects perceived study performance importance (Resolution)
baseline_groups.notes: Coef=0.150, p=0.687. Not significant in Resolution.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Signal affects perceived job performance importance (No-Resolution)
Signal affects perceived job performance importance (Resolution)
baseline_groups.notes: Coef=0.231, p=0.512. Not significant in Resolution.

global_notes: Lab experiment on motivated beliefs with 200 subjects. The 2x2 design (Resolution/No-Resolution x Good/Bad signal) creates 4 cells for belief updating and 4 for secondary outcomes (study/job performance). Many specs split by treatment-signal cell. The key finding is the asymmetry in No-Resolution (strong good, weak bad) that disappears in Resolution.
